metadata.title: The role of magnetite/graphene oxide nano-composite as a high- efficiency adsorbent for removal of phenazopyridine residues from water samples, an experimental/theoretical investigation

sections.text:
The role of magnetite/graphene oxide nano-composite as a highefficiency adsorbent for removal of phenazopyridine residues from water samples, an experimental/theoretical investigation
Hassan Karimi-Maleh, Marjan Shafieizadeh, Mohammad A. Taher, Francis Opoku, Ephraim Muriithi Kiarii, Poomani Penny Govender, Sara Ranjbari, Morteza Rezapour, Yasin Orooji
PII: S0167-7322(19)33498-1 DOI: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.molliq.2019.112040 Reference: MOLLIQ 112040
To appear in: Journal of Molecular Liquids
Received date: 21 June 2019 Revised date: 19 October 2019 Accepted date: 29 October 2019

The role of magnetite/graphene oxide nano-composite as a high-
efficiency adsorbent for removal of phenazopyridine residues from
water samples, an experimental/theoretical investigation
Hassan Karimi-Maleh, a,b,c* Marjan Shafieizadeh, d Mohammad A. Taher* d , Francis Opoku, c Ephraim Muriithi Kiarii, c Poomani Penny Govender, c Sara Ranjbari b , Morteza Rezapour e ,
Yasin Orooji f
a School of Resources and Environment, University of Electronics Science and Technology of China (UESTC),
Postal code 611731
b Department of Chemical Engineering, Laboratory of Nanotechnology, Quchan University of Technology, Quchan,
Islamic Republic of Iran
c Department of Applied Chemistry, University of Johannesburg, P. O. Box 17011, Doornfontein Campus, 2028,
Johannesburg, South Africa
d Department of Chemistry, Bahonar University, Kerman, Iran
e IP Department, Research Institute of Petroleum Industry (RIPI), P.O. Box 14665-137, Tehran, Iran
f College of Materials Science and Engineering, Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing, 210037, P. R. China
*Corresponding Authors: E-mail address: hassan@uestc.edu.cn and h.karimi.maleh@gmail.com (H.K.Maleh); ma-
taher@uk.ac.ir (M.A. Taher)
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
Abstract Presence of phenazopyridine residues in water resources can be harmful to human body, hence it is very important to remove them from aqueous media. In this study, a magnetic nano-composite adsorbent, i.e. reduced graphene–iron oxide (rGO–Fe3O4) was synthesized and used for removal of phenazopyridine residues from wastewater samples. Experimental parameters influencing adsorption process were optimized, and results showed a sorption capacity of 14.064 mg g -1 at pH= 6.0 for phenazopyridine. Under the best experimental condition, rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite showed an efficiency of 91.4% for removal of phenazopyridine in aqueous solution. Adsorption of phenazopyridine on flat and parallel oxygen and iron–terminated rGO–Fe3O4 surfaces was studied by density functional theory calculations. It was found that, in case of both oxygen and iron–terminated rGO–Fe3O4 surfaces, phenazopyridine prefers to interact with aromatic ring and amino flat to oxygen–terminated rGO–Fe3O4 surface, as opposed to iron–terminated sites due to enhanced charge migration at the interface. Negative adsorption energy revealed that formation of phenazopyridine@ rGO–Fe3O4 is an exothermic process, confirming stability of these species.
Keywords: Magnetite/graphene oxide nanocomposite, Phenazopyridine removal, Adsorption, Kinetic investigation, DFT investigation
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Release of pollutants into water poses many risks to human health, and is also harmful to aquatic life [1]. On the other hand, presence of drug residues in wastewater or soil can be harmful to plants and human [2, 3], creating important challenges for application of drugs [4]. Sources of water pollution are wastewaters produced from hospitals, agriculture as well as industrial and domestic activities [5]. Most of medicines coming into wastewater are absorbed by activated sludge processes in treatment systems, transferring them from liquid to solid phases [6, 7]. As a remedy, the application of advanced treatment processes has a good efficiency in removing such micro contaminants [8, 9]. Due to the importance of water recycling, global focus on wastewater removal has increased in recent years [10-15]. Phenazopyridine is an azo-derivative dye with pharmaceutical applications excreted through urine [16-18]. Unwanted administration of phenazopyridine, e.g. through polluted water samples can lead to emergence of symptoms such as headache and upset stomach. This compound can also cause changes in skin or eye pigments making them turn into a noticeable yellowish color. Therefore, it is very important to remove phenazopyridine residues from wastewater. Nanomaterials such as carbon nanotubes, graphene, polymer nanowires, metal oxide nanoparticles, etc. are unique due to their properties like considerably high surface area [19-27]. These materials have been used for removal of pollutants [28-32], fabrication of sensors for biological and pharmaceutical materials [33-40], energy storage systems [41], super-capacitors [42], batteries [43] and drug delivery [44]. Different types of nanomaterials such as metalorganic framework [45], iron nanoparticle [46] and nano-clay composite [47] have been suggested as adsorbents for removal of drugs from water samples. Compared to reported adsorbents, rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite has shown more advantages such as enjoying a high surface area contributing to more recovery percentage in pollutant removal. Due to good
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
regeneration of rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite, this adsorbent is very cost-effective for industrial applications. With regard to this fact, the present study was conducted aimed at synthesis and application of rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite, as a high -performance adsorbent for removal of phenazopyridine from water samples. Results of experiments indicated that, developed adsorbent showed considerable ability for removal of phenazopyridine in water samples. Additionally, a Density Functional Theory (DFT) study was performed to comprehend nature of adsorption sites, as well as structure and interaction energy between phenazopyridine residues and rGO–Fe3O4.

sections.heading: 2.1. Apparatus and chemicals
sections.text: Analytical grade phenazopyridine, iron(II) chloride, iron(III) chloride, sodium hydroxide, graphite powder, hydrogen chloride, sulfuric acid, sodium nitrate and potassium permanganate were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Co. An Agilent Cary® 50 UV–Visible spectrophotometer was used for absorbance studies. A KYKY-EM3200 digital scanning electron microscope was also used for morphological evaluation of rGO–Fe3O4. 0.1–15 ppm solutions of phenazopyridine were prepared and used in the experiments.

sections.heading: 2.2. Synthesis of rGO–Fe3O4
sections.text:
Graphene oxide was synthesized according to Hummers’ Method [40]. According to this method, 4.0 and 2.0 mmol of FeCl3.6H2O, and 2.0 FeCl2.4H2O were mixed in water to reach a final volume of 100 mL in an Erlenmeyer as well as having a solution with an initial pH of 1.48, which was then increased to 4.0 by adding 1.0 M sodium hydroxide. Next, 50 mL of a 0.55 - mg/mL GO mixture was added to this solution under high stirring speed for 30 min, and pH was
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
increased to 10.0 by adding 0.1 M sodium hydroxide and stirring for another 30 min at room temperature. Obtained black precipitate was separated using a magnet and was washed five times with deionized water and ethanol before drying in an oven at 65 ° C for 50 h. The following reaction was suggested in this study for synthesis of rGO–Fe3O4.
2Fe 3+ + Fe 2+ +GO +8OH -  GO + 2 Fe(OH)3  rGO.Fe3O4 (s) + 4H2O (1)
2.3. Real sample preparation Five milliliters of the water or waste-water samples were centrifuged for 20 min at 1500 rpm and then filtered using a 0.45-μm filter. The obtained solution was transferred into the cell to remove phenazopyridine while applying the optimal conditions.

sections.heading: 2.4. Removal tests
sections.text:
Batch mode investigations were performed to remove phenazopyridine. The rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite was separated using a 4-T magnet. UV-VIS spectroscopy tests were performed to monitor equilibrium concentrations of phenazopyridine, and adsorption isotherms were studied at a wavelength of ~426 nm. After optimizing effective parameters, different models were evaluated to describe thermodynamic and kinetic behaviors of the parameters. The following equation was used for evaluating removal percentages.
%Removal = [(C0 –Ci)/C0]100 (2)
Where, Ci and C0 are final and initial concentrations of phenazopyridine (mg L −1 ).

sections.heading: 2.5. Computational Details
sections.text:
The mechanism for the interaction of phenazopyridine with particles of the rGO–Fe3O4 nano– composite was studied within the framework of the plane–wave DFT as implemented in the
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
Cambridge Serial Total Energy Package code [48] of Material Studio 2016 Package [49]. The periodic plane–wave approach, with the ultrasoft pseudopotential [50] and Perdew–Burke– Ernzerhof [51] exchange–correlation functional of the generalized gradient approximation were employed to account for the ion–core electron interactions and the exchange–correlation effects, respectively. The dispersion forces were corrected using the empirical formula of Grimme [52]. In all calculations, a 12 x 12 x 1 k–point sampling of Monkhorst–Pack method [53] was used. A kinetic energy cut–off of 500 eV was used in the systems studied . Geometry optimizations were carried out using the BFGS scheme [54] with force, energy and displacement convergence criterion of 0.3 eV/Å, 10 –6
eV/atom, and 0.01 Å, respectively. The adsorption energy (Eads) was
calculated as:
( – ) – (3)
where
( – ) , – and are the total energies of the combined system (phenazopyridine@ rGO–Fe3O4), adsorbents (rGO–Fe3O4) and adsorbate (phenazopyridine), respectively. A negative value of signifies that the adsorption process is exothermic and the rGO–Fe3O4 nano–composite is stable. By this definition, the more negative value of , the stronger the adsorption process.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite
sections.text:
The rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite samples were subjected to X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) analyses. Figure 1A shows the XRD pattern of the rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite in the 2θ range of
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
0–90°. The distinct peaks were used to calculate the grain size via Scherrer’s equation, expressed as follows: “Here Figure 1”
D=Kλ/(β cosθ) (4)
The grain size of the Fe3O4 nanoparticles was 12.0 nm. The (002) plane of graphene was observed in the 2θ range of 20.0-30.0 degrees. The presence of planes with miller indexes (220), (311), (400), (422), (511), (440), (620) and (533) confirmed the synthesis of Fe3O4 with a cubic structure. Figure 1(b) presents Transmission Electron Microscopic (TEM) image of rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite. Presence of graphene nano-sheets and Fe3O4 onto graphene layers confirmed formation of rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite. Energy-Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopic (EDS) spectrum of rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite is presented in Fig. 2(a). Presence of C, Fe, and O elements confirms purity of synthesized nanocomposite. Super-paramagnetic properties of rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite were investigated by VSM analyses at room temperature. Figure 2(b) exhibits hysteresis loop of rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite with a saturation magnetization of 18.269 emu/g and a coercive force (Hc) of 0.0922 Oe, suggesting rGO–Fe3O4 enjoys super-paramagnetic properties. Fig.2(b) illustrates a typical figure for magnetic effect of rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite suspension on water before and after using a magnet. As shown in Fig.2 (b), after using the magnet, rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite moves toward magnets, confirming effective magnetic properties of rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite.
“Here Figure 2”
BET analysis was performed to investigate specific surface areas of rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite. A typical N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm of rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite is shown in Fig. 3.
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
Results revealed type IV curves with H3-hysteresis loops for a mesoporous structure with a specific surface area of 213 m 2 /g and a pore size of 0.2309 cm 3 /g. “Here Figure 3”

sections.heading: 3.2. UV-Vis analyses
sections.text: The presence of residual amounts of phenazopyridine after adsorption experiments was checked through UV-Vis spectroscopy, showing two absorbance bonds at ~280 nm and ~426 nm. The absorbance band at ~426 nm was used for quantitative analyses (Fig. S1; supplementary information data).

sections.heading: 3.3. Optimization of the adsorption process
sections.text: To obtain the best removal condition, the effects of pH, contact time, mass of adsorbent, and temperature on adsorption of phenazopyridine were optimized.

sections.heading: 3.3.1. Effect of pH
sections.text:
The effect of pH on removal efficiency and capacity of phenazopyridine was investigated in pH window of 3.0 to 8.0. Values used for rest of the parameters were 5 min for contact time, 10.0 μg L −1 for concentrations of phenazopyridine, 0.6 g L −1 for mass of adsorbent, and 298 K for temperature. Obtained data are presented in Fig. 4. By changing pH from 3.0 to 6.0, removal efficiency increased, while removal efficiency decreased in a range of 6.0 - 8.0. Presence of hydronium ions in spaces between graphene layers under acidic conditions is an important barrier against adsorption of phenazopyridine. In basic pH, negative charge of drug and surface of nano-sheets act as a repulsive force, lowering adsorption efficiency. Considering these
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
observations, a pH of 6.0 was chosen as optimal value and was applied to rest of the experiments. “Here Figure 4” 3.3.2. The effect of the adsorbent dose Adsorbent dose is one of the most important factors in effective removal of pollutants. To determine optimal value of this parameter, various amounts of adsorbent ranging from 0.15 to 1.0 g L −1 were used in experiments, while rest of the factors were kept constant (contact time=5 min, pH=6.0, pollutant concentration=10 μg L −1 , and temperature = 298 K). Maximum removal of phenazopyridine was observed in presence of 0.8 g L −1
of rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite as the
adsorbent (Fig. 5(a)). No change was observed in removal efficiency in values higher than this value. Therefore, a concentration of 0.8 g L −1
of rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite was used throughout
rest of the experiments. “Here Figure 5”

sections.heading: 3.3.3. Effect of the contact time
sections.text: Figure 5(b) shows a plot of removal efficiency vs. contact time in presence of 10.0 μg L −1 of phenazopyridine, and 0.8 g L −1 of the adsorbent for different contact times. As illustrated in Fig.5 (b), maximum removal efficiency was obtained at 7.0 min, and it remained constant after this time.

sections.heading: 3.3.4. Optimal temperature
sections.text:
The process was performed at various temperatures of 285, 298, 305, and 315 K, while other factors were kept at their optimal values, and based on results, (Fig. 5(b)) the best removal efficiency was observed at a temperature of 298 K. Thus, this temperature was chosen as an optimal value and was applied to rest of the experiments.
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of

sections.heading: 3.4. Analytical range for the removal of phenazopyridine
sections.text: Adsorption ability of rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite was investigated over a wide concentration range of phenazopyridine under optimum conditions. The rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite showed a linear dynamic range for removal of phenazopyridine in a concentration range of 0.25-14.0 ppm (A=0.0724 C+0.014, where C is ppm concentration of phenazopyridine, and A is absorbance of phenazopyridine in presence of rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite).

sections.heading: 3.5. Adsorption isotherms
sections.text:
Freundlich and Langmuir models were selected and evaluated to describe the adsorption phenomena of the adsorption process. The isotherm plots of the Freundlich and Langmuir models are presented in Fig. S2. In addition, the values of the parameters for the isothermal models at different temperatures are presented in Tables 1. According to the obtained curves and data, the Langmuir model had a higher regression coefficient (R 2 ), confirming that the sorption of phenazopyridine follows this model and hence a monolayer of the pollutant covers the rGO– Fe3O4 adsorbent. “Here Table 1” The thermodynamic parameters (ΔG°, ΔS°, and ΔH°) were also determined at 298 °K (see table 2). The free energy change (ΔG°) was determined according to equation (1):
∆G°= ‒ RT Ln K° (1)
where K° is the sorption equilibrium constant. The standard entropy change (∆S°) and standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) were determined at 298 °K according to equations (2 and 3), respectively:
∆S° = (∂∆G°/∂T)P (2) ∆H° = ∆G° + T∆S° (3)
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
where R (8.314 J mol -1 K -1 ) and T (K) are the ideal gas constant and temperature in Kelvin, respectively. “Here Table 2”

sections.heading: 3.6. Adsorption kinetics
sections.text: Pseudo-first-order and pseudo-second order models were applied to investigate adsorption kinetics of phenazopyridine removal in this study. Plots of pseudo-first and pseudo-second order models are illustrated in Figures S3A and S3B, respectively. A higher regression coefficient (R 2 ) was observed for pseudo-second order model as opposed to pseudo-first-order model (see Table 3), confirming pseudo-second-order nature of phenazopyridine adsorption. “Here Table 3”

sections.heading: 3.7. Density functional theory
sections.text:
The mechanism of the interaction of phenazopyridine with rGO–Fe3O4 nano–composite was further demonstrated using DFT calculations. The interaction of phenazopyridine was considered to occur on oxygen and iron terminated sites of the rGO–Fe3O4 nano–composites. The most stable optimized structures of phenazopyridine on each site are shown in Fig. 6.
“Here Figure 6”
Several flat and parallel ads rption configurations were structurally optimized and compared for the adsorption of phenazopyridine on the oxygen– and iron–terminated rGO–Fe3O4 surfaces. In the flat configurations (Str 1 and Str 4), both the aromatic ring and the amino group of phenazopyridine were placed above the rGO surface. In other configurations, phenazopyridine was oriented in such a way that the main axis of the hydro groups on the aromatic ring (Str 2 and Str 5) and the amino group (Str 3 and Str 6) pointed parallel to the rGO surface. Similar adsorption configurations were found to be the most stable on both surfaces (Fig. 5). Evaluations
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
revealed that the amino group plays a more important role than the hydro group in the parallel adsorption of the phenazopyridine molecule on the oxygen– and iron–terminated rGO–Fe3O4 surfaces. As shown in Fig. 6, the Eads value of Str 1 mode on the oxygen–terminated surface was –7.56 eV, which was much higher than that of Str 2 (–3.65 eV) and Str 3 (–4.10 eV). The same conclusion can be made for the iron–terminated configurations. Furthermore, the adsorption was strongest on the oxygen–terminated rGO–Fe3O4 surface than on the iron–terminated rGO–Fe3O4 surface. Therefore, the oxygen–terminated surface was a good descriptor for the adsorption of phenazopyridine on rGO–Fe3O4 surface.

sections.heading: 3.8. Electronic properties
sections.text:
To evaluate the influence of phenazopyridine adsorption on the electronic structure of rGO– Fe3O4 surface, the density of states (DOS) values of phenazopyridine before and after adsorption were determined and analyzed (Fig. 7). After adsorption, the DOS of phenazopyridine was completely different from that of isolated phenazopyridine, showing the chemisorption state of phenazopyridine drug. Thus, the strong interaction between the rGO–Fe3O4 and the adsorbed phenazopyridine results in the broadening and shifting of the DOS peaks of the adsorbed phenazopyridine molecule, signifying a chemical adsorption. This indicates that the electron densities within the phenazopyridine molecule changed during the adsorption process because of charge transfer. “Here Figure 7”
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of

sections.heading: 3.9. Charge transfer
sections.text:
To quantitatively evaluate the amount of charge transfer and understand the underlying physical mechanism of the electronic properties of phenazopyridine@ rGO–Fe3O4, the three–dimensional (3D) charge density difference (CDD), defined as the difference between the total charge density of phenazopyridine@ rGO–Fe3O4 and the sum of the charge densities of the isolated rGO–Fe3O4 and adsorbed phenazopyridine were determined. The iso-surface plots of CDD for phenazopyridine@rGO–Fe3O4 (Fig. 8) showed a strong accumulation of electrons on the rGO– Fe3O4 surface and depletion of electrons on the adsorbed phenazopyridine.
“Here Figure 8”
Based on the CDD plots in Fig. 10, a significant charge transfer occurs between phenazopyridine and rGO–Fe3O4. Further insights into the nature of the interactions of the phenazopyridine molecule with the rGO–Fe3O4 surface were obtained through Hirshfeld charge analysis [55]. The Hirshfeld charge transfer values of Str 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6 were found to be 0.60, 0.39, 0.58, 0.36, 0.19 and 0.36 |e|, respectively. All the optimized phenazopyridine@ rGO–Fe3O4 configurations were observed to have a positive charge migration value, showing that the electrons were transported from the phenazopyridine molecule to rGO–Fe3O4 surface [56]. The charge transfer was the lowest for phenazopyridine adsorption on the iron–terminated rGO–Fe3O4 surface, correlating to their lowest adsorption energy values, signifying less favorability of phenazopyridine adsorption on iron–terminated rGO–Fe3O4 surface, where the interaction of phenazopyridine in the flat mode was enhanced on both surfaces.
3.10. Analysis of real samples
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
Application of rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite for the removal of phenazopyridine was checked in water and waste water samples. According to Table 4, the recoveries of the spiked samples were in the range of 89.3-91.3%, demonstrating that rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite can be effectively used for the removal of phenazopyridine from aqueous solution. To investigate the advantage of rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposites over Fe3O4 nanoparticles, the removal efficiency for phenazopyridine was investigated by using Fe3O4 nanoparticle; the results are presented in Table 4. As can be seen, the rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite shows more advantage compared to Fe3O4 nanoparticle for the removal of phenazopyridine due to the high surface area of RG. “Here Table 4”

sections.heading: 3.11. Regeneration of rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite adsorbent
sections.text: Economic status of rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite was ascertained by a recycling method. A 96.5% regeneration of rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite adsorbent was found in the solution containing 0.2 M HCl. On the other hand, regenerated rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite was used up to 10 batch operations. Results showed an increase in the removal capacities from 84 to 93%.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In this study, for the first time, synthesis of rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite, as a high -efficiency adsorbent (uptake of phenazopyridine ~91.4%) was evaluated. The rGO–Fe3O4 was synthesized through a co-precipitation method, and grain size of Fe3O4 nanoparticles was determined as 12.0 nm. The Langmuir isotherms and a pseudo-second -order kinetic model were suggested for uptake of phenazopyridine at a surface of rGO–Fe3O4. Using DFT technique, adsorption behavior of phenazopyridine molecule on rGO–Fe3O4 surface was studied; performed based on electron density, density of states, and Hirshfeld charge analysis to understand their interaction
Jo ur
na l P
re -p
ro of
modes. The most prominent adsorption site of phenazopyridine on rGO–Fe3O4 surface was also identified, where adsorption was more preferred on flat oxygen terminated RG–Fe3O4 surface compared to iron terminated surface. The rGO–Fe3O4 nanocomposite was used as a regenerable and cheap adsorbent with high performance ability for removal of phenazopyridine in waste samples. Accordingly, proposed adsorbent can be applied to industrial applications.
Jo ur
na l P
re -p

The periodic plane–wave approach, with the ultrasoft pseudopotential [50] and Perdew–Burke– Ernzerhof [51] exchange–correlation functional of the generalized gradient approximation were employed to account for the ion–core electron interactions and the exchange–correlation effects, respectively.

Further insights into the nature of the interactions of the phenazopyridine molecule with the rGO–Fe3O4 surface were obtained through Hirshfeld charge analysis [55].

All the optimized phenazopyridine@ rGO–Fe3O4 configurations were observed to have a positive charge migration value, showing that the electrons were transported from the phenazopyridine molecule to rGO–Fe3O4 surface [56].

metadata.abstractText: This is a PDF file of an article that has undergone enhancements after acceptance, such as the addition of a cover page and metadata, and formatting for readability, but it is not yet the definitive version of record. This version will undergo additional copyediting, typesetting and review before it is published in its final form, but we are providing this version to give early visibility of the article. Please note that, during the production process, errors may be discovered which could affect the content, and all legal disclaimers that apply to the journal pertain.
